articles.headline: Touting Virus Cure, ‘Simple Country Doctor’ Becomes a Right-Wing Star
articles.snippet: How Dr. Vladimir Zelenko’s claims for his coronavirus treatment spread from a New York village all the way to President Trump.
articles.abstract: How Dr. Vladimir Zelenko’s claims for his coronavirus treatment spread from a New York village all the way to President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, residents of Kiryas Joel, a New York village of 35,000 Hasidic Jews roughly an hour’s drive from Manhattan, began hearing about a promising treatment for the coronavirus that had been rippling through their community.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Trump’s Company Seeks to Ease Financial Crunch as Coronavirus Takes Toll
articles.snippet: As companies nationwide look for relief, the Trump Organization has talked with Deutsche Bank and a Florida county about delaying payments on some loans and other obligations.
articles.abstract: As companies nationwide look for relief, the Trump Organization has talked with Deutsche Bank and a Florida county about delaying payments on some loans and other obligations.
articles.lead_paragraph: All over the country, businesses large and small are seeking breathing room from their lenders, landlords and business partners as they face the financial fallout from the coronavirus crisis.
articles.byline: By David Enrich, Ben Protess and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Trump Promotes Oil Deal That May Not Exist
articles.snippet: The president’s optimism for a deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce production and a Saudi call for talks send crude prices skyrocketing, but Moscow showed little enthusiasm.
articles.abstract: The president’s optimism for a deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce production and a Saudi call for talks send crude prices skyrocketing, but Moscow showed little enthusiasm.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When oil prices crashed in early March after a dispute between Russia and Saudi Arabia, President Trump put a positive spin on the news. “Good for the consumer, gasoline prices coming down!” he wrote on Twitter as markets tumbled. On Tuesday, Mr. Trump said that falling gasoline prices amounted to “the greatest tax cut we’ve ever given.”
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley, Clifford Krauss and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Take Government Aid? We’ll See, Some Businesses Say
articles.snippet: Executives at Boeing, for one, have indicated that they might not accept money authorized by the stimulus if they dislike the terms.
articles.abstract: Executives at Boeing, for one, have indicated that they might not accept money authorized by the stimulus if they dislike the terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Grants, low-interest loans and other government support might seem like manna for businesses under financial strain. But some chief executives and corporate boards might balk at the offer of billions of dollars in aid to help them ride out the coronavirus pandemic and keep the economy from sliding into a deep recession.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis, Niraj Chokshi and David Gelles

articles.headline: How Tech’s Lobbyists Are Using the Pandemic to Make Gains
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley hasn’t suffered from the same financial devastation as other industries. Tech companies still have an agenda to push.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley hasn’t suffered from the same financial devastation as other industries. Tech companies still have an agenda to push.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, lobbying groups representing advertising giants like Google and Facebook asked California’s attorney general to wait to enforce the state’s new online privacy rules given the coronavirus ripping around the world.

articles.headline: Decade of Job Growth Comes to an End, Undone by a Pandemic
articles.snippet: After an expansion that added 22 million to U.S. payrolls, March registered a loss, and worse is yet to come.
articles.abstract: After an expansion that added 22 million to U.S. payrolls, March registered a loss, and worse is yet to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: The longest stretch of American job creation on record came to a halt last month, the Labor Department reported Friday, another reflection of the coronavirus pandemic that has brought the economy to a virtual standstill.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: It’s Bedlam in the Mask Market, as Profiteers Out-Hustle Good Samaritans
articles.snippet: Hospitals, governments, do-gooders and hucksters are all competing. Scams and prices are soaring.
articles.abstract: Hospitals, governments, do-gooders and hucksters are all competing. Scams and prices are soaring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Susan Houghtelling, a hospital supply-chain manager in upstate New York, was facing a shortfall of medical supplies when her inbox suddenly flooded with offers.

articles.headline: ‘A Seismic Shock’: Jittery Companies Pull Back on Ads During Pandemic
articles.snippet: Blank billboards and canceled online ads signal an industry in crisis as the coronavirus spreads. “There are things happening that we’ve never seen before,” one marketing executive said.
articles.abstract: Blank billboards and canceled online ads signal an industry in crisis as the coronavirus spreads. “There are things happening that we’ve never seen before,” one marketing executive said.
